comments.html:
The usual solution to that is called a "superscope" on the DHCP server (at least on MS DHCP servers). The server uses, e.g., the first available address from any of the subnets comprising the superscope.

If specific hosts shall receive addresses from specific subnets, then this needs to be configured explicitly on the DHCP server (e.g., based on client ID).
comments.name: Erik Auerswald

comments.html: Daniel, DHCP server "shared network" and vendor specific tricks like "dhcp smart relay" can address the problem you mention.
comments.name: Jeff Behrns

comments.html: One of the biggest limitations I've seen in using multiple IPv4 subnets on a single interface was the fact that DHCP Relay can only be used for the primary subnet, as there is no way for the switch/router to distinguish in which of the configured subnets the host is requesting IP in.
comments.name: Daniel

comments.html: I think that a 1: 1 relationship between VLANs and subnets avoids the complexities of either using multiple subnets in a single VLAN or splitting a single subnet across several VLANs. Keeping things simple helps operating the network.
comments.name: Erik Auerswald

comments.html:
I agree that for Dual-Stack IPv4 and IPv6 there should usually be a 1: 1:1 relationship (1 VLAN, 1 IPv4 subnet, 1 GUA IPv6 subnet) unless there is a good reason for something else.

IPv6 always adds link-local addressing, and there may be reasons for additional IPv6 on-link prefixes.

IMHO needless complexity should be avoided.
comments.name: Erik Auerswald

comments.html: Perhaps 1: 1 for each IP version? We can argue about "best", but every modern OS out there assigns one of each to every interface by default...
comments.name: Jeroen van Bemmel

comments.html: The sentence that „If you have multiple subnets on a single VLAN, then (in the IPv4 world) the hosts have to send traffic to other hosts on the same VLAN through a router.“ does not make sense to me. If I split these multiple subnets across multiple VLANs, the traffic still needs to be sent through the same router.
comments.name: Arne
